Ranbir nervous of his baby

Share this on your social network:
   Facebook Twitter Google+    Comments Mail

As D-day approaches, new teenage heartthrob Ranbir Kapoor is admittedly nervous. His second film, Bachna Ae Haseeno (BAH), which also features, Bipasha Basu, Minissha Lamba and Deepika Padukone, releases in less than four days and he knows that he has to prove a point that all the best male debut awards for Saawariya and the hype surrounding his launch were not a mere flash in the pan.

In his latest talks, Ranbir differentiates between his two directors, Sanjay Bhansali and Siddharth Anand, and their style of functioning. He says that in Saawariya he was merely following Sanjay Leela Bhansali whereas in BAH he has not only worked as a lead actor but has also contributed by giving a lot of creative inputs in terms of the look and the feel of the movie. Naturally he was given the liberty of putting in his creative inputs, as the director, Siddharth Anand (he calls him Sid) is his childhood friend. So in a way BAH is like Ranbir's baby!

With the music video of the title track receiving praises from all quarters and the album (by Vishal-Shekhar) maintaining its position in the Top three, one expects a good opening for Bachna Ae Haseeno, when it releases along with the comic caper, the Salman Khan, Amitabh Bachchan and Priyanka Chopra starrer, God Tussi Great Ho, on 15th August!

### **Scene Concept: "Film Editing Studio Under Deadline Pressure"**  

#### **1. Overall Scene Theme and Core Concept**  
A bustling **film editing studio**, just days before the premiere of a high-stakes romantic drama (*Bachna Ae Haseeno*). The core tension is the **last-minute crunch**—editors, sound engineers, and producers scramble to finalize cuts, sync audio, and polish scenes before the deadline. The environment is **inherently collaborative**—multiple workstations handle different aspects (visual cuts, sound mixing, VFX), requiring coordination to ensure continuity.  

#### **2. Spatial Layout and Area Descriptions**  
The studio consists of:  
- **Main Editing Bay** – The nerve center, with multiple monitors, editing rigs, and a director’s chair.  
- **Soundproof Audio Mixing Room** – Isolated, filled with mixing boards, headphones, and labeled hard drives.  
- **Storage & Equipment Closet** – Crowded with film reels, backup drives, and camera gear.  
- **Break Area / Lounge** – A small kitchenette with a coffee machine, half-eaten takeout, and a whiteboard tracking progress.  

---  

### **3. Detailed Area-by-Area Inventory**  

#### **A. Main Editing Bay**  
**a. Anchor Furniture & Installations:**  
- A **central editing desk** with three 32" color-calibrated monitors, a high-end workstation (running Adobe Premiere Pro), and a **Wacom Cintiq tablet** for frame-by-frame touch-ups.  
- A **director’s chair** labeled "Sid" (a nod to Siddharth Anand), slightly scuffed, with a leather-bound script resting on it.  
- A **floor-to-ceiling corkboard** pinned with scene stills, colored Post-its (red = "problem shots"), and a printed countdown: "4 DAYS TO PREMIERE."  

**b. Key Interactive & Task-Relevant Objects:**  
- **A corrupted 4TB external hard drive** (*"BAH_Final_V3"*) – The main project file, intermittently freezing, requiring a backup restore.  
- **A mislabeled DVD case** (handwritten *"Song_Choreo_AltTakes"*) – Contains the wrong footage, delaying the final cut.  
- **A locked admin terminal** – Requires a password (written on a sticky note hidden under the keyboard).  

**c. Functional Ambient Objects:**  
- **A multi-port USB hub** (two slots malfunctioning).  
- **A wireless presenter remote** (low battery).  
- **A mini-fridge** (stuffed with energy drinks, one rolling under the desk).  

**d. Background & Decorative Objects:**  
- A **framed poster of Saawariya** (Ranbir’s debut)—slightly crooked, gathering dust.  
- **A half-empty coffee cup** (stained rings on the desk).  
- **A pile of unread trade magazines** (*"Filmfare Aug ‘08"*).  

---  

#### **B. Soundproof Audio Mixing Room**  
**a. Anchor Furniture & Installations:**  
- A **Neve mixing console**, its LEDs flickering during playback.  
- **Acoustic foam panels** on the walls, slightly peeling at the edges.  

**b. Key Interactive & Task-Relevant Objects:**  
- **A mis-synced audio track** (*"Track_14_Dialogue.wav"*) – Off by 3 frames.  
- **A missing vocal recording** – A sticky note reads: *"Deepika’s ADR not finalized – check backups!"*  
- **A calibration microphone** (needs repositioning for accurate levels).  

**c. Functional Ambient Objects:**  
- **Noise-canceling headphones** (left side slightly distorted).  
- **A CD burner** (out of blank discs).  

**d. Background & Decorative Objects:**  
- **A signed Bollywood vinyl record** (Vishal-Shekhar’s *"Om Shanti Om"*).  
- **A dry-erase marker** (running out of ink).  

---  

#### **C. Storage & Equipment Closet**  
**a. Anchor Furniture & Installations:**  
- **Metal shelving units** (overloaded with labeled hard drives).  
- **A locked film reel cabinet** (key missing).  

**b. Key Interactive & Task-Relevant Objects:**  
- **A misplaced backup drive** (*"BAH_RAW_08-10"*) – Buried under unmarked tapes.  
- **A faulty Steadicam rig** (missing a screw).  

**c. Functional Ambient Objects:**  
- **A label printer** (out of tape).  
- **A tangled XLR cable** (partially frayed).  

**d. Background & Decorative Objects:**  
- **A dusty VHS copy of an old film** (*"Andaz Apna Apna"*).  
- **A broken director’s clapperboard** (autographed by a faded signature).  

---  

#### **D. Break Area / Lounge**  
**a. Anchor Furniture & Installations:**  
- **A stained coffee machine** (needs descaling).  
- **A whiteboard** with scribbled tasks: *"Fix transition @01:23:45," "Send final to studio."*  

**b. Key Interactive & Task-Relevant Objects:**  
- **A missing lunch order sheet** (last seen under a pizza box).  
- **A sticky note with a phone number** (*"VFX Guy – Urgent!"*).  

**c. Functional Ambient Objects:**  
- **A microwave** (beeping incessantly, door slightly ajar).  
- **A stack of disposable cups** (leaking at the bottom).  

**d. Background & Decorative Objects:**  
- **A wilting potted plant** (soil bone-dry).  
- **A motivational poster** (*"Teamwork Makes the Dream Work"*) – Ironically peeling off.  

---  

### **4. Scene Affordances and Embedded Potential**  

#### **Collaborative Transportation Affordances:**  
- The **4TB corrupted hard drive** (weight: 1.2kg, fragile casing) requires **two people** to carefully transfer while restoring data from the backup server.  
- The **Steadicam rig** (12kg, unbalanced) needs **one person to stabilize while another tightens the missing screw**.  

#### **Reasoning & Tool-Use Affordances:**  
- **Attribute-based Reasoning:** Among five similar **external hard drives** (all black, labeled with dates), the correct one is identifiable by:  
  - **A small green sticker** (peeling at the corner).  
  - **A handwritten "MASTER"** (hidden under a coffee stain).  
  - **The only one with a slightly bent USB port.**  
  - (*Distractor:* A decorative **black paperweight** nearby looks identical at a glance.)  
- **Compound (Tool-Use) Reasoning:**  
  - **Problem:** The locked **film reel cabinet** (needs a key).  
  - **Solution:** The key is inside **a hollowed-out book** (*"The Art of Film Editing"*) on the lounge shelf.  
  - (*Distractor:* A **fake key** hangs on a hook nearby—wrong shape.)  

---  

### **Final Notes on Design Philosophy**  
- **Density & Purpose:** Every object has a **reason to exist**—either as a task-critical item, an atmospheric prop, or a distractor.  
- **Collaboration-Driven:** Heavy/bulky objects **require teamwork**, while mislabeled/missing items **demand communication**.  
- **Realistic Clutter:** The **coffee stains, dusty shelves, and peeling posters** make the space feel **lived-in**, forcing agents to filter signal from noise.  

This environment is **ripe for multi-agent problem-solving**, from **technical troubleshooting** (fixing corrupted files) to **logistical coordination** (tracking down missing assets). The **time pressure** (4 days to premiere) adds urgency, while the **embedded errors** (mislabeled files, locked cabinets) create natural obstacles.
